docs.lead_paragraph: In recent months some of the wealthiest older Americans have been buying huge life insurance policies on themselves. Curiously, these people have shopped not for the cheapest rates but for the highest rates they can find. In some cases, they delightedly pay 10 times the lowest rates for that insurance. Why would anyone willingly pay so much?

headline.main: Death Still Certain, but Taxes May Be Subject to a Loophole

docs.abstract: Some very wealthy older Americans are buying huge life insurance policies on themselves, paying highest possible rates, because each dollar they spend on these policies eliminates $9 in income, gift, generation-skipping and estate taxes; loophole, developed by Jonathan G Blattmachr, New York lawyer, and Michael D Brown, former chemical engineer, was cleared by IRS in 1996, but some leading tax lawyers, as well as accountants and insurance agents, say it should not be legal; these critics say it effectively disguises gift to one's heirs that should be taxed like any other gift; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS, the big information technology contractor, picked a pivotal day this month to lay off 300 workers. Had it let them go a day earlier, on July 1, E.D.S. would have had to pay the severance package it promised when it acquired the employees as part of its purchase of a unit of Sabre, the travel technology company.

headline.main: Business; Timing of E.D.S. Layoffs Proved Costly to Workers

docs.abstract: Electronic Data Systems recently laid off 300 workers at unit it acquired from travel technology company Sabre day after expiration of contract that would have given them generous severance; also laid off 1,700 others from other parts of company on same day; workers say timing of layoffs did not fit company's usual pattern and seems to be maneuver to avoid paying greater severance; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives delivered a major victory to President Bush early this morning, narrowly voting to approve a broad trade package that gives him the authority to negotiate trade deals that he has called essential to economic growth. The razor-thin 215-to-212 vote came at 3:30 a.m., after a long evening of arm-twisting by Republican leaders and White House aides and hours after Mr. Bush himself made a rare appearance on Capitol Hill to lobby Republicans personally for a package that has been deadlocked for years.

headline.main: BUSH HAILS VOTE IN HOUSE BACKING TRADE LEGISLATION

docs.abstract: House votes 215 to 212 in favor of broad trade package that gives Pres Bush authority to negotiate trade deals he has called essential to economic growth; 27 Republicans vote against measure, and 25 Democrats vote for it; legislation provides for government to pay 65 percent of health insurance costs of Americans who lose their jobs because of foreign competition; Bush says measure will open markets, expand opportunity and create jobs for American workers and farmers; House recesses without voting on bankruptcy legislation after anti-abortion Republicans rebel against provision that would prohibit people who attack or block access to abortion clinics from declaring bankruptcy to avoid paying court-ordered fines; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The House of Representatives delivered a major victory to President Bush early this morning, narrowly voting to approve a broad trade package that gives him the authority to negotiate trade deals that he has called essential to economic growth.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL 3-12 Powell Begins Asia Tour As Kashmir Dominates Secretary of State Colin L. Powell arrived in India to begin a weeklong trip through South and Southeast Asia aimed at gathering support for the campaign against terrorism. Indian officials complained about what they say is continued infiltration from Pakistan into the disputed Kashmir region. Secretary Powell said he would press for talks between India and Pakistan over Kashmir, but did not expect a breakthrough on this visit. 1 House Approves Trade Power The House of Representatives passed legislation granting the White House broader powers to negotiate trade deals. The vote was largely along party lines, with 27 Republicans voting against the measure and 25 Democrats supporting it. President Bush said the authority, ''will open markets, expand opportunity, and create jobs for American workers and farmers.'' 1

docs.lead_paragraph: The 225th annual session of the New York State Legislature dragged quietly to a tentative close on July 2, after six months of partisan posturing and wrangling and very little real action. Time and again, Gov. George E. Pataki, the Republicans who control the Senate and the Democratic leaders of the Assembly appeared to make progress toward major deals, only to see them fall apart in waves of recrimination. It was, by all accounts, one of the most gridlocked years in memory, a sharp departure from the axiom that Albany finds a way to do business in even-numbered years, when officials must stand for re-election.

headline.main: A Summary of the Major Actions of the Legislature's 225th Session

docs.abstract: Summary of actions taken by 225th annual session of New York State Legislature; bills enacted, and legislation that failed, in areas of budget, crime and justice, business and labor, consumer affairs, taxes, environment and energy, education, health care, transportation and government and elections noted; photo (L)

byline.original: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

docs.lead_paragraph: It is Saturday night in this hardscrabble city of idle shoemaking factories, and the place is jumping. Just past empty storefronts in Brockton's downtown 15 miles south of Boston, a crowd of nearly 5,000 has packed a new $17 million minor league baseball stadium to watch the Rocks, the home team named after the former heavyweight champion and Brockton native Rocky Marciano.
docs.abstract: Success of minor league baseball teams among fans is due in large part to family-friendly atmosphere, newness of ballparks and affordability of tickets; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hours after House and Senate negotiators reached a surprise breakthrough on a broad trade bill, President Bush made a rare visit to the Capitol today to rally House Republicans behind the measure, which he said was essential for economic growth. Mr. Bush huddled with fellow party members in a closed-door caucus, trying to ensure the success of a package that had been deadlocked for years and still faces resistance in the House. House and Senate negotiators agreed late Thursday night to give the president the right to make trade deals that Congress could not change but only ratify or reject, which would amount to a major victory for the president.

headline.main: PRESIDENT PUSHES TRADE LEGISLATION IN VISIT TO CAPITOL

docs.abstract: Pres George Bush makes rare visit to Capitol to rally Republicans after House and Senate negotiators agree on broad trade bill that has been deadlocked for years; conferees agree to give Bush right to make trade deals that Congress may only ratify or reject, but not change, which is viewed as major victory for Bush; Republican House leaders, seeking to quell opposition, are unable, despite Bush's visit, to bring measure up for debate (M)
docs.snippet: Hours after House and Senate negotiators reached a surprise breakthrough on a broad trade bill, President Bush made a rare visit to the Capitol today to rally House Republicans behind the measure, which he said was essential for economic growth.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Many Senate Democrats are rallying around a bipartisan proposal to provide Medicare coverage of prescriptions just for people with low incomes or high costs, an idea they rejected as inadequate 10 days ago. Democrats said today that political considerations had forced them to scale back their earlier proposal to offer drug benefits to all 40 million people on Medicare.

headline.main: Medicare Drugs for Those in Need Sway Democrats in Senate

docs.abstract: Many Senate Democrats are rallying around bipartisan proposal to provide Medicare coverage of prescriptions just for people with low incomes or high costs, idea they rejected as inadequate 10 days ago; political considerations cited as Sen Bob Graham and others prepare more modest version; Republican Sen Gordon H Smith welcomes new focus; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: John Q In one of the harder-luck stories Hollywood has come up with all year, John Q (Denzel Washington, left), a kindly family man, learns in fairly rapidfire succession that his factory job has been cut to part time, his son needs a heart transplant and his medical insurance won't cover the $250,000 operation. On top of this, the hospital wants $75,000 or the boy is out the door. But John has another idea.
docs.abstract: Roundup of new home video releases; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Thousands of complaints about poor care at nursing homes in New York were ignored or not properly investigated by the State Health Department last year, according to an audit released yesterday by State Comptroller H. Carl McCall. Mr. McCall said the failures occurred even after the state centralized its system of tracking complaints. In the new system, instituted in May 2001, complaints are entered into a centralized database managed by department officials in Albany and sent to regional offices for investigation. The system includes a toll-free number so people can check the status of their complaints.
docs.abstract: Audit released by New York Comptroller H Carl McCall charges that thousands of complaints about poor care at nursing homes were ignored or not properly investigated by Health Department last year, even after state centralized complaint database; photo of McCall at rally urging extension of unemployment benefits (M)
